sect2.title: Configuration Workflow
sect2.para: Network configuration is mainly used to connect a single workstation to an Ethernet-based LAN. It is commonly configured before &ay; starts, to fetch the profile from a network location. This network configuration is usually done through linuxrc

note.title: The linuxrc program
note.para: For a detailed description of how linuxrc works and its keywords, see .

sect2.para: By default, &yast; copies the network settings that were used during the installation into the final, installed system. This configuration is merged with the one defined in the &ay; profile.

&ay; settings have higher priority than any existing configuration files. &yast; will write ifcfg-* files based on the entries in the profile without removing old ones. If the DNS and routing section is empty or missing, &yast; will keep any pre-existing values. Otherwise, it applies the settings from the profile file.

note.title: Use &ay; network settings during installation
note.para: If network settings are needed during the installation, you can force &ay; to write and apply them before registration takes place by setting the setup_before_proposal option to true. Asking &ay; to set up the network in the early stages is useful when installation on a network is needed, but the configuration is too complex to define it using linuxrc (see ).
If the configuration is written at the end of installation, it will not be applied until the system is rebooted.

sect2.para: Network settings and service activation are defined under the profile networking global resource.

sect2.title: The Network Resource

example.title: Network configuration
example.screen: <networking> <dns> <dhcp_hostname config:type="boolean">true</dhcp_hostname> <hostname>linux-bqua</hostname> <nameservers config:type="list"> <nameserver>&dnsip;</nameserver> <nameserver>&dnsip117;</nameserver> <nameserver>&dnsip118;</nameserver> </nameservers> <resolv_conf_policy>auto</resolv_conf_policy> <searchlist config:type="list"> <search>&exampledomain;</search> <search>&exampledomain1;</search> </searchlist> </dns> <interfaces config:type="list"> <interface> <bootproto>dhcp</bootproto> <name>eth0</name> <startmode>auto</startmode> </interface> </interfaces> <ipv6 config:type="boolean">true</ipv6> <keep_install_network config:type="boolean">false</keep_install_network> #false means use Wicked, true means use NetworkManager <managed config:type="boolean">false</managed> <net-udev config:type="list"> <rule> <name>eth0</name> <rule>ATTR{address}</rule> <value>&wsImac;</value> </rule> </net-udev> <s390-devices config:type="list"> <listentry> <chanids>0.0.0800:0.0.0801:0.0.0802</chanids> <type>qeth</type> </listentry> </s390-devices> <routing> <ipv4_forward config:type="boolean">false</ipv4_forward> <ipv6_forward config:type="boolean">false</ipv6_forward> <routes config:type="list"> <route> <destination>&subnetnatmask;</destination> <name>eth1</name> <extrapara>scope link src &subnetnat;.100 table one</extrapara> <gateway>-</gateway> </route> <route> <destination>default</destination> <name>eth1</name> <gateway>&subnetnat;.1</gateway> </route> <route> <destination>default</destination> <name>lo</name> <gateway>&gateip;</gateway> </route> </routes> </routing> </networking>

sect2.para: As shown in the example above, the <networking> section can be composed of a few subsections:

listitem.para: interfaces describes the configuration of the network interfaces, including their IP addresses, how they are started, etc.
dns specifies DNS related settings, such as the host name, the list of name servers, etc.
routing defines the routing rules.
s390-devices covers s390-specific device settings.
net-udev enumerates the udev rules used to set persistent names.

sect2.para: Additionally, there are a few elements that allow modifying how the network configuration is applied:

listitem.para: As described in , by default, &ay; merges the network configuration from the running system with the one defined in the profile. If you want to use just the configuration from the profile, set this element to false. The value is true by default.
Determines whether to use NetworkManager instead of Wicked.
Forces &ay; to restart the network just after writing the configuration.
Use the network configuration defined in the profile during the installation process. Otherwise, &ay; relies on the configuration set by linuxrc.

After setting up the network, &ay; checks whether the assigned IP address is duplicated. In that, it shows a warning whose timeout is controlled by this element. If it is set to 0, the installation is stopped.

tip.title: IPv6 address support
tip.para: Using IPv6 addresses in &ay; is fully supported. To disable IPv6 Address Support, set <ipv6 config:type="boolean">false</ipv6>

sect2.title: Interfaces
sect2.para: The interfaces section allows the user to define the configuration of interfaces, including how they are started, their IP addresses, networks, and more. The following elements must be enclosed in <interfaces>...</interfaces> tags.

listitem.para: Boot protocol used by the interface. Possible values:
static for statically assigned addresses. It is required to specify the IP using the ipaddr element.
dhcp4, dhcp6 or dhcp for setting the IP address with DHCP (IPv4, IPv6 or any).
dhcp+autoip to get the IPv4 configuration from Zeroconf and get IPv6 from DHCP.
autoip to get the IPv4 configuration from Zeroconf.
ibft to get the IP address using the iBFT protocol.
none to skip setting an address. This value is used for bridges and bonding slaves.

sect2.title: Persistent Names of Network Interfaces
sect2.para: The net-udev element allows to specify a set of udev rules that can be used to assign persistent names to interfaces.

entry.para: Network interface name, for example eth3.
ATTR{address} for a MAC based rule, KERNELS for a bus ID based rule.
For example: f0:de:f1:6b:da:69 for a MAC rule, 0000:00:1c.1 or 0.0.0700 for a bus ID rule.

tip.title: Handling Collisions in Device Names
tip.para: When creating an incomplete udev rule set, the chosen device name can collide with existing device names. For example, when renaming a network interface to eth0, a collision with a device automatically generated by the kernel can occur. &ay; tries to handle such cases in a best effort manner and renames colliding devices.

example.title: Assigning a Persistent Name Using the MAC Address

sect2.title: Domain Name System
sect2.para: The dns section is used to define name-service related settings, such as the host name or name servers.

listitem.para: Host name, excluding the domain name part. For example: foo instead of foo.bar. The Linux kernel allows using the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) in place of the host name, and so does &yast;. However, this is not the correct usage in the dns section of &yast;. The resolver should determine the FQDN. (See "THE FQDN" section of man 1 hostname for information on how FQDNs are resolved.)
If a host name is not specified and is not taken from a DHCP server (see dhcp_hostname), &ay; will generate a random hostname.
List of name servers. Example:
Search list for host name lookup.
Optional.
Specifies whether the host name must be taken from DHCP or not.

sect2.title: Routing
sect2.para: The routing table allows to specify a list of routes and the packet forwarding settings for IPv4 and IPv6.

entry.para: Whether IP forwarding must be enabled for IPv4.
Whether IP forwarding must be enabled for IPv6.

sect2.para: The following settings describe how routes are defined.

listitem.para: Required: Route destination. An address prefix can be specified, for example: 192.168.122.0/24.
The heading default can be used to indicate that the route is the default gateway in the same address family (ipv4 or ipv6) as the gateway
Required: Interface associated to the route.
Optional: Gateway's IP address.
(Deprecated.) Destination's netmask.
Specifying the prefix as part of the destination value is preferred.
Optional: Further route options like the metric, mtu or table.

example.title: Network routing configuration
example.screen: <routing> <ipv4_forward config:type="boolean">true</ipv4_forward> <ipv6_forward config:type="boolean">true</ipv6_forward> <routes config:type="list"> <route> <destination>&subnetnatmask;</destination> <device>eth1</device> <extrapara>scope link src &subnetnat;.100 table one</extrapara> </route> <route> <destination>default</destination> <device>eth1</device> <gateway>&subnetnat;.1</gateway> </route> <route> <destination>default</destination> <device>lo</device> <gateway>&gateip;</gateway> </route> </routes> </routing>

sect2.title: s390 Options
sect2.para: The following elements must be between the <s390-devices>...</s390-devices> tags.

listitem.para: qeth, ctc or iucv
channel ids separated by a colon (preferred) or a space
boolean; default: false
QETH port name (deprecated since SLE 12 SP2openSUSE 42.2)
CTC / LCS protocol, a small number (as a string)
optional
IUCV router/user

sect2.para: In addition to the options mentioned above, &ay; also supports &zseries;-specific options in other sections of the configuration file. In particular, you can define the logical link address, or LLADDR (in the case of Ethernet, that is the MAC address). To do so, use the option LLADDR in the device definition.

tip.title: LLADDR for VLANs
tip.para: VLAN devices inherit their LLADDR from the underlying physical devices. To set a particular address for a VLAN device, set the LLADDR option for the underlying physical device.

sect2.title: Proxy
sect2.para: Configure proxies for HTTP, HTTPS, and FTP with http_proxy, https_proxy and ftp_proxy, respectively. Addresses or names that should be directly accessible need to be specified with no_proxy (space separated values). If you are using a proxy server with authorization, fill in proxy_user and proxy_password,
